cat1.title: GENERAL INFORMATION
cat1.description: Transboundary Animal Diseases (TADs) are highly contagious epidemic diseases that can spread extremely rapidly, irrespective of national borders. They can cause high rates of death and/or disease in animals, thereby having serious socio-economic and sometimes public health consequences while constituting a constant threat to the livelihoods of livestock farmers.

ask1.title: 1) Has your country identified a list of Priority Transboundary Animal Diseases (TADs)?

oneOf.title: Yes
oneOf.description: If yes, list the 5 diseases with the highest priority for your country:

cat3.description: Farm register refers to a national identification system, supported by the appropriate national regulation, which assigns a unique identification number to premises and owners within a country.

cat4.description: Animal identification and recording (AIR) refers to a national identification and recording system, supported by the appropriate national regulation, which assigns a unique identification number for 			individual animals or groups of animals.

ask9.title: 9) When an outbreak of FMD is identified, is there a system in place to carry out an outbreak epidemiological investigation?

enum: Lack of capabilities of skilled human resources

ask10.title: 10) From the following list, which activities are undertaken during an FMD outbreak investigation

ask10_1.title: Identification of risk factors for clinical FMD

ask10_2.title: Supporting farmers in preventing further spread of infection and taking care of affected livestock

ask10_3.title: Forward and backward tracing – attempting to identify routes of FMD virus transmission

ask10_4.title: Sampling are taken for confirmation and send to an FMD laboratory for diagnosis

ask10_5.title: Identification of the virus is followed by identification of the serotype

ask10_6.title: Samples are sent either to a regional or to an international Reference Laboratory for further analysis

ask11.title: 11) What additional control measures are applied when an outbreak occurs in your country?

cat7.title: CONTROL PLAN
cat7.description: Control plans are sets of well-structured and clearly-stated documents that describe policies, strategies and procedures for effective disease-control response to high-threat diseases, such as FMD.

ask12.title: 12) Does your country have a written and government endorsed FMD Control Plan?

ask13.title: 13) If Yes, is this control plan developed along the lines of a Risk-Based Strategy?
ask13.description: In a risk-based strategy the intervention measures target risk hotspots. These measures are selected according their effectiveness at reducing the probability of occurrence and spread of FMD.as well as the impact of an outbreak. Usually these measures will be identified through risk analysis

ask14.title: 14) Has the country conducted FMD simulation exercises?
ask14.description: Simulation exercises: The purpose of simulation exercises for FMD is to test and strengthen the management response to events involving and FMD outbreak. This includes testing the country capacity to	communicate within and between the countries and with international organizations, and the ability to prioritise tasks at national and local level.

ask14_1.title: If Yes, when was the last simulation exercise performed?

ask15.title: 15) In which situations is your country’s FMD Control Plan implemented?
enum: On a change in the epidemiological situation.
The Control Plan is written but rarely or never applied.

ask16.title: 16) Is the written FMD Control Plan available?

cat8.title: IDENTIFICATION OF RISK FACTORS AND HOTSPOTS
cat8.description: Risk factors are those management, environmental, socio-economic and production factors that increase the	risk of introduction of FMD infection and / or transmission. For example: trading cattle back and forward from animal markets is an important risk factor for both introduction and transmission of the FMD virus. Risk factor is an epidemiological term, identified through statistical analysis.

ask17a.title: 17 a) Has your country determined the risk factors for FMD introduction?

oneOf.title: Yes
oneOf.description: Which risk factors (maximum five) have been identified?

ask17b.title: 17 b) Has your country identified the ris factors for FMD spread?

oneOf.title: Yes
oneOf.description: Which risk factors (maximum five) have been identified?

ask18.title: 18) Has your country determined risk hotspots for FMD?
ask18.description: Risk hotspots are defined as geographical areas, production sectors, age categories or practices conducted by people that pose a particular high risk of FMD transmission or that suffer a great impact from FMD infection. Risk hotspots are determined based on the collation of surveillance information from different sources such as value-chain analysis, impact assessment, serological studies, etc.

oneOf.title: Yes
oneOf.description: Could you please list a maximum of five risk hotspots that have been identified?

enum: Apply for official OIE recognition of FMD free with vaccination
Apply for official OIE recognition of FMD free without vaccination
Apply for official OIE recognition of FMD free with vaccination
Apply for official OIE recognition of FMD free without vaccination

aks21.title: 21) What are the key indicators to know if your FMD control strategy is working?

cat10.title: SOCIO-ECONOMIC IMPACT
cat10.description: Social indicators include for example impact in poverty, whether related to income or social and living conditions, and access to adequate nutrition. Economic indicators include public and private costs of an outbreak, as well as the costs of the measures taken in order to control or prevent the disease and disease outbreaks.

cat11.title: SEROSURVEILLANCE
cat11.description: Serosurveillance refers to the implementation a a sampling protocol aiming to gather serological evidence of FMD virus circulation by detection of antibodies against non-structural proteins (NSPs) of FMD virus in	serum samples, which is used as an indicator of virus exposure.
